title: Cross Fell
text:
Cross Fell is the highest <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in the <a href="Pennines">Pennine Hills</a> of <a href="Northern%20England">Northern England</a> and the highest point in England outside the <a href="Lake%20District">Lake District</a>. It is located in the <a href="North%20Pennines">North Pennines</a> <a href="Area%20of%20Outstanding%20Natural%20Beauty">Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty</a>. It lies within the county of <a href="Cumbria">Cumbria</a> and the historic county boundaries of <a href="Cumberland">Cumberland</a>.
The summit, at , is a stony <a href="plateau">plateau</a>, part of a ridge running north-west to south-east, which also incorporates <a href="Little%20Dun%20Fell">Little Dun Fell</a> at and <a href="Great%20Dun%20Fell">Great Dun Fell</a> at . The three adjoining <a href="fell">fell</a>s form an <a href="escarpment">escarpment</a> that rises steeply above the <a href="River%20Eden%2C%20Cumbria">Eden Valley</a> on its south-western side and drops off more gently on its north-eastern side towards the <a href="River%20Tyne">South Tyne</a> and <a href="River%20Tees">Tees</a> Valleys.
Cross Fell summit is crowned by a cross-shaped dry-stone shelter. On a clear day there are excellent views from the summit across the Eden Valley to the mountains of the Lake District. On the northern side of Cross Fell there are also fine views across the <a href="Solway%20Firth">Solway Firth</a> to the <a href="Southern%20Uplands">Southern Uplands</a> of <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>.
The fell is prone to dense hill fog and fierce winds. A shrieking noise induced by the <a href="Helm%20Wind">Helm Wind</a> is a characteristic of the locality. It can be an inhospitable place for much of the year. In ancient times it was known as "Fiends Fell" and believed to be the haunt of evil spirits. <a href="St%20Augustine%20of%20Canterbury">St Augustine of Canterbury</a> is said to have blessed the hill when he arrived here on his travels so it became known as Cross Fell in the Christian tradition, although it has been speculated that the fell became known as Cross Fell ("cross" meaning "angry") because of the evil spirits.
Local geography.
Cross Fell and the adjoining fells are mainly a bed of hard, <a href="carboniferous%20limestone">carboniferous limestone</a>. Where this bed surfaces, there are steep rock faces. There are also <a href="stratum">strata</a> of <a href="shale">shale</a> and <a href="gritstone">gritstone</a> that surface on the fell. On the south and west facing slopes of Cross Fell the rock faces have been broken up by frost action to give a <a href="scree">scree</a> slope made up of large boulders. The local terrain shows obvious evidence of recent glaciation and is covered by thin soil and acidic <a href="peat">peat</a>.
Cross Fell, Great Dun Fell and Little Dun Fell form a block of high terrain which is all over in elevation. This is the largest block of high ground in England and tends to retain snow-cover longer than neighbouring areas. Snow can be found in gullies on the north side of Cross Fell as late as May in most years. In some years, lying snow has been known to persist until July and fresh snowfall in June (mid-summer in the Northern Hemisphere) is common.
<a href="Precipitation%20%28meteorology%29">Precipitation</a> on Cross Fell averages around per year. Local flora includes a number of rare alpine plants such as the <a href="Micranthes%20stellaris">Starry Saxifrage</a> and a mountain <a href="Forget-me-not">Forget-me-not</a>. Cross Fell is covered by what is known as "siliceous alpine and boreal grassland". It is the southernmost outlier of this vegetation type, which is common to highlands in Scotland and <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>. It is a designated <a href="Special%20Area%20of%20Conservation">Special Area of Conservation</a> (SAC). Local farmers are required to keep free-roaming sheep off the tops of the fells in order to avoid damaging the natural flora.
Cross Fell is a conspicuous feature in the landscape. It dominates the skyline on almost the entire length of the <a href="A66%20road">A66 trunk road</a> between <a href="Penrith%2C%20Cumbria">Penrith</a> and <a href="Stainmore">Stainmore</a>. It can also be seen from many points in the Lake District, including the <a href="Helvellyn">Helvellyn</a> summit, and from high ground throughout <a href="Dumfriesshire">Dumfriesshire</a> and <a href="Northumberland">Northumberland</a>. Most remarkably, it is claimed that it is visible in exceptional circumstances from the summit of <a href="Carnedd%20Llewelyn">Carnedd Llewelyn</a> in <a href="Snowdonia">Snowdonia</a> (<a href="Wales">Wales</a>) at a distance of .
